text: :The junior homonym Coenobita Gistl, 1848 is now the moth genus Ectropis. The genus Coenobita contains 17 species of terrestrial hermit crabs. ==Ecology== Coenobita species carry water in the gastropod shells they inhabit, allowing them to stay out of water for a long time. ==Distribution== The majority of the species are found in the Indo-Pacific region, with only one species in West Africa, one species occurring along the Atlantic coast of the Americas, and one species occurring on the Pacific coast of the Americas. {|class="wikitable sortable" !Image !! Species !! Authority !! Year !! Distribution |- |120px|| Coenobita brevimanus || Dana || 1852 || Indo-Pacific |- | ||Coenobita carnescens || Dana || 1851 || Pacific Ocean |- |120px|| Coenobita cavipes || Stimpson || 1858 || Indo-Pacific |- |120px|| Coenobita clypeatus || || 1787 || Western Atlantic |- |120px||Coenobita compressus || || 1836 || Eastern Pacific |- | || Coenobita longitarsis || De Man || 1902 || East Indies |- | ||Coenobita olivieri || Owen || 1839 || Pacific Ocean |- |120px|| Coenobita perlatus || || 1837 || Indo-Pacific |- | || Coenobita pseudorugosus || Nakasone || 1988 || Indo-Pacific |- |120px|| Coenobita purpureus || Stimpson || 1858 || Japan |- | ||Coenobita rubescens || Greeff || 1884 || West Africa |- |120px||Coenobita rugosus || || 1837 || Indo-Pacific |- | ||Coenobita scaevola || || 1775 || Indian Ocean, Red Sea |- | ||Coenobita spinosus || || 1837 || Polynesia & Australia |- |120px|| Coenobita variabilis || McCulloch || 1909 || Australia |- |120px|| Coenobita violascens || Heller || 1862 || Pacific Ocean |} ==Taxonomy== Coenobita is closely related to the coconut crab, Birgus latro, with the two genera making up the family Coenobitidae. The name Coenobita was coined by Pierre André Latreille in 1829, from an Ecclesiastical Latin word, ultimately from the Greek , meaning "commune"; the genus is masculine in gender. ==References== ==External links== * Category:Hermit crabs Category:Terrestrial crustaceans
title: Coenobita
